3. X-ray tomography

Contents

  • Step 1: import
  • Step 2: define objective by specifying data path
  • Step 3: solve
  • Step 4: display

3. X-ray tomography#

Step 1: import#

import numpy as np

from cofi.cofi_objective import XRayTomographyObjective
from cofi.optimisers import ScipyOptimiserSolver
from cofi.linear_reg import LRNormalEquation

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ModuleNotFoundError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
Input In [1], in <cell line: 3>()
      1 import numpy as np
----> 3 from cofi.cofi_objective import XRayTomographyObjective
      4 from cofi.optimisers import ScipyOptimiserSolver
      5 from cofi.linear_reg import LRNormalEquation

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cofi.cofi_objective'

Step 2: define objective by specifying data path#

xrt_obj = XRayTomographyObjective("dataset/data_xrt.dat")

Step 3: solve#

# scipy_solver = ScipyOptimiserSolver(xrt_obj)
# scipy_model = scipy_solver.solve()
# print(scipy_model.values())

linear_reg_solver = LRNormalEquation(xrt_obj)
linear_reg_model = linear_reg_solver.solve()
print(len(linear_reg_model.values()))
print(linear_reg_model.values())

/Users/nancyh/Documents/work/lab/cofi/cofi/linear_reg/_utils.py:6: UserWarning: You are using linear regression formula solver, please note that this is only for small scale of data
  warn(

2500
[1.02742538 0.77349135 0.97755961 ... 1.05056014 0.78230165 1.01236865]

Step 4: display#

xrt_obj.display(scipy_model)
xrt_obj.display(linear_reg_model)

It appears that the result given by Scipy optimizer (using its default method) is very badâ€¦ In contrast, with the information that this problem is linear, using a normal equation solver is much better in this case.
